dataset.title: Macrosystems Results for ITS in 7 Plot Soil Samples (UCLUST - Resampled)

creator.organizationName: University of Oklahoma - Institute for Environmental Genomics

para.literalLayout: Patterns of biodiversity, such as the increase toward the tropics and the peaked curve during ecological succession, are fundamental phenomena for ecology. Such patterns have multiple, interacting causes, but temperature emerges as a dominant factor across organisms from microbes to trees and mammals, and across terrestrial, marine, and freshwater environments. However, there is little consensus on the underlying mechanisms, even as global temperatures increase and the need to predict their effects becomes more pressing. The purpose of this project is to generate and test theory for how temperature impacts biodiversity through its effect on biochemical processes and metabolic rate. A combination of standardized surveys in the field and controlled experiments in the field and laboratory measure diversity of three taxa -- trees, invertebrates, and microbes -- and key biogeochemical processes of decomposition in seven forests distributed along a geographic gradient of increasing temperature from cold temperate to warm tropical. This data set captures abundance of OTUs (Operational Taxonomic Units) sampled for in forest soils at the original six sampling sites (HJ Andrews, Niwot, Harvard Forest, Coweeta, Luquillo, Barro Colorado Island) plus the new site set up by the Enquist Lab at Mt. Bigelow near Tucson, AZ. This data represents abundance of ITS (fungi) genes in soil samples processed by the University of Oklahoma Institute for Environmental Genomics as part of a macrosystems biodiversity and latitude project supported by the National Science Foundation under Cooperative Agreement DEB#1065836.

contact.organizationName: University of Oklahoma - Institute for Environmental Genomics

para.literalLayout: An array of 21 1m2 subplots was used to sample leaf litter invertebrates and soil microbes at each experimental site. The subplots were directed 1m, 10m, 50m, 100m and 200m from a central subplot where the "1m" plots shared an edge with the central subplot. The leaf litter and litter soil interface were sifted and placed in berlese funnel extractors for 48 hours, with litter invertebrates extracted into 95% ethanol. Within each 1m2 plot, 9 soil cores (2cm diameter, ~8cm depth) were taken with all 9 pooled and mixed. Files in this data set are based on resampled data. Taxonomic information was generated by RDP classifier (https://rdp.cme.msu.edu/classifier/classifier.jsp). MP7.ITS.UCLUST.rep_seq.res.fasta includes representative sequence of each OTU. MP7.ITS.UCLUST.rep_seq_aligned.res.fasta is the sequence file after alignment. MP7.ITS.UCLUST.tree.res.nwk is phylogenetic tree file generated by FastTree.

dataTable.entityName: Macrosystems Results for ITS in 7 Plot Soil Samples (UCLUST)
dataTable.entityDescription: Abundance of OTUs and taxonomies for ITS (fungi) genes in 7 plot soil samples (resampled, generated by UClust).

attribute.attributeDefinition: Code defining the sampling location consisting of one letter specifying the site (A = HJ Andrews, B = Barro Colorado, C = Coweeta, H = Harvard Forest, L = Luquillo, M = Mt. Bigelow, N = Niwot Ridge) and then a number that shows the location in meters of the subplot (1m, 10m, 50m, 100m and 200m from a central subplot where the "1m" plots shared an edge with the central subplot), and a letter defining direction (N = North, S = South, E = East, W = West). Example: C200N = Coweeta, 200 meters north of the exact center of the plot. Example: LC = Luquillo, exact enter of the plot. Example: M1S = Mt. Bigelow, 1 meter south of the exact center of the plot.

textDomain.definition: Code defining the sampling location consisting of one letter specifying the site (A = HJ Andrews, B = Barro Colorado, C = Coweeta, H = Harvard Forest, L = Luquillo, M = Mt. Bigelow, N = Niwot Ridge) and then a number that shows the location in meters of the subplot (1m, 10m, 50m, 100m and 200m from a central subplot where the "1m" plots shared an edge with the central subplot), and a letter defining direction (N = North, S = South, E = East, W = West). Example: C200N = Coweeta, 200 meters north of the exact center of the plot. Example: LC = Luquillo, exact enter of the plot. Example: M1S = Mt. Bigelow, 1 meter south of the exact center of the plot.

attribute.attributeDefinition: The abundance of the identified gene at each location.

textDomain.definition: The abundance of the identified gene at each location.

otherEntity.entityDescription: This file contains the exact sequence of the four nucleotides for each Operational Taxonomic Unit (OTU) after alignment. A, C, G, and T represent the four nucleotide bases of a DNA strand — adenine, cytosine, guanine, thymine. Note: The original file extension is .fasta (it was changed to .txt in order to upload).

This file contains the non-aligned sequence of the four nucleotides for each Operational Taxonomic Unit (OTU). A, C, G, and T represent the four nucleotide bases of a DNA strand — adenine, cytosine, guanine, thymine. Note: The original file extension is .fasta (it was changed to .txt in order to upload).
Phylogenetic tree file generated by FastTree. Note: The original file extension for this file is .nwk (it was changed to .txt for upload purposes).
